channel.title: Math issue
channel.description:
I am trying to calculate a position offset for my object and I'm not sure on the math behind it. I have drawn a diagram to try and explain the situation
[img]http://i66.tinypic.com/e5r2pv.png[/img]
Currently the object's position, is drawn as the green circle in the image. I am trying to calculate how to move to the red circle, drawn in the image. I have the direction vector, which is the blue line. I have tried adding and subtracting values from the x/z axis but then I realised that this will need to be calculated each update because when the object rotates about its origin, the offset positions for x/z are going to change.
Similar to the object's origin (green circle) being an anchor point, and we're swinging round the anchor point at a fixed distance, in sync with the camera's angle, I just don't know how to go about it, anyone know how to do this?
ps this is in 3d

item.title: Math issue
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

(x,y)_i = (.5, .5);
d(x,y) = (.5, -.5);
(x,y)_f = (x_i + [dx*t], y_i + [dy*t]);

I wrote it in more of a physics/linal vector notation but, that’s basically all you have to do. You take the direction vector, turn it into a unit vector, then multiply that by the amount of time that passes and its speed to find out how far it’s supposed to go in each direction. Then you just add the x,y components of that new value to the initial x,y position and you get the final x,y position

I’m not sure what else you were asking for. Camera rotations are handled through matrices too

item.title: Math issue
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

Hm so if I understand what you’re asking, you want to know how to move in a direction that is defined by a unit vector?

//This is how you calculate the direction vector I believe
Vector direction = new Vector(0, 0, 1);
direction.rotateY(angleY); // pitch
direction.rotateX(angleX); // yaw
direction.rotateZ(angleZ); // roll
direction.unit();

so to calculate the new position after an X-step (X being a value that represents movement speed), add this to your vector class (arg ‘scalar’ is the X-step)


	public void subtract(Vector v, float scalar) {
		x -= v.x * scalar;
		y -= v.y * scalar;
		z -= v.z * scalar;
	}

To move towards the direction vector, assuming ‘position’ is a 3D vector,

[code]
float xStep = 0.1f;
position.subtract(direction, xStep);

// or to move away from the direction vector,
position.subtract(direction, -xStep);[/code]
